div.sent: The imaginary line passing north-south through the centre of the earth, and around which the earth rotates is the axis of the earth.
The northernmost point of this axis is known as north pole and the southernmost point is called the south pole.
Both poles are at the same distance from the earth's equator.
Keeping both the poles in equal distance, an imaginary line has been drawn which has encircled the globe from west to east.
This is known as the Equator or the terrestrial equator.
Due to spherical nature of the earth this line is also circular.
The equator has divided the earth into two equal parts.
The part of earth lying north to the equator is known as the northern hemisphere, and that to the south as the southern hemisphere.
With the help of the equator one can determine the angular distance of a place situated either in the northern or in the southern hemisphere.
This series of east-west-running circles is known as the meridians of latitude.
The angular distance of a place north or south of the equator gives the latitude of that place.
Considering the equator as to be at 0o, latitudes north and south to it extend up to 90o north and south.
The angles are divided into degrees, minutes and seconds.

The value of the angle that is formed through those two lines is equivalent to the latitude of that particular place.
Therefore, the latitude is the angular distance of a place north or south of the equator.
If a line is drawn from any place to its centre then that line will create an angle with the equatorial plane.
The value of that angle is the latitude of that place.
The latitudes are parallel to one another and every one of them is a full circle.
The circumferences of the latitudes are decreased with the increase of their values.
Some of the parallels are quite famous.
The 23.5o latitudes in the northern and southern hemispheres are known as the Tropic of Cancer and the Tropic of Capricorn respectively.
The region of the earth between the Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn is the tropical region.
Besides, the 66.5o north and south latitudes are known as Arctic and Antarctic circles respectively.
The earth is a spherical planet.
Towards her eastern and western sides the earth does not have any specific boundary which can be taken as the end or border.
Although the equator was an obvious choice as the prime parallel for latitude, being the largest, no one meridian was uniquely qualified as prime longitude.
In 1884, an international prime meridian, passing through London's Greenwich Observatory, was officially designated.
An imaginary line that encircles the earth through the middle from east to west is known as the equator.
These lines are the lines of longitude.
The longitudes are also known as meridians.
Any of these meridians can be taken as prime meridian and angular distance of other meridians can be measured from the prime meridian.
Longitude of any given point on the globe is measured as angular distance eastward or westward from the prime meridian at Greenwich.
Thus, the total number of meridians are divided equally at 180 eastern and western longitudes, which is virtually the same line.
Like that of the latitudes, the longitudes can also be divided into minutes and seconds.
A metallic marker there indicates its exact location of the prime meridian on a map.
The longitude at 180 is also the International Date Line.

There are different methods of determining the latitude of a place.
In other words, the degree of latitude of any place in the northern hemisphere is equivalent to the degree of altitude of pole star.
So, the latitude of any place in the northern hemisphere can be deducted from the altitude of the pole star.
With the help of pole star: North star or pole star is a conspicuous star, in the night sky, in the northern hemisphere.
Every night from any place of the northern hemisphere one can see the pole star in a fixed position in the northern sky.
But the altitude of the pole star from the horizon does not remain the same.
It differs with the difference of place, which means, the altitude of the pole star in the horizon is different for different places.
In the equator the location of the pole star is in the horizon and its altitude is 0.
Longitude of a place can be determined by two methods'by the differences of local time, and by Greenwich mean time.
By the differences of local time: The earth is a sphere that is moving continuously around its axis from west to east.
Consequently different places of the earth face the sun at different time.
The earth rotates through 360 in 24 hours, or it covers a distance of 1 every 4 minutes.
If the difference of time in two places is 1 hour, then the longitude passing through the two places is 15 apart.
The place with time 1 hour ahead will be east of the other place.
Thus, if the longitude of a place is known, then the longitude of another place can be determined.

The longitude of the place mentioned can be determined from the difference of time that occurs between the indicated place and Greenwich.

The usefulness of latitude and longitude are mentioned below.
It helps to determine the location of any point on earth surface with accuracy.
The latitude of a place helps to indicate the temperature of place, that is how cold or warm it is.
Longitude helps to determine the time of a place.
Different places that fall on the same longitude experience noon at the same time.
Besides, if an aeroplane or a ship is in trouble, the crew can radio message its location by longitude and latitude.
With the help of the longitudinal and latitudinal coordination the rescue team can reach the spot quickly.
Local time: Everyday the earth moves round its axis from west to east.
Consequently, the sun appears in the eastern parts of the globe before the western parts.
Due to rotation of the earth the sun reaches its highest altitude on a certain place and that hour is treated as 12.00 noon.
On the basis of this noon time the other hours of the day are determined.
The time thus determined is taken as the local time.
Places on different longitudes have different local time.
For example, when it is 10.00 a.m. in Karachi, it is 11.00 a.m. in Dhaka.
This is because the difference in longitude between the two places is 15.
Standard time: Most of the countries of the world extend between two or more longitudes.
So, one country may have several local times.
This would create confusion in maintaining time among the different parts of the same country and disrupt the daily activities of the nation.
To avoid this confusion each of the countries of the world has introduced the concept of maintaining the standard time.
The time at 90 east is considered as the standard time for Bangladesh.
The time at 82.5 east is the local time at Allahabad, which is taken as the standard time of India.
The time towards east of prime meridian is ahead, while that towards west is after that of the time at Greenwich.
Hence, when it is Thursday 10.00 a.m. at Greenwich, at 30 east it is Thursday 12.00 noon.
And by the same calculation, at 180 east it will be Thursday 10.00 p.m.
But it cannot be 10.00 p.m. Wednesday and Thursday at the same time in same place.
This is known as the International Date Line.
The earth is orbiting continuously around the sun.
That is the earth is in continuous motion.
The earth has two basic motions'rotation around its axis, and revolution around the sun along its orbit Rotation:
The earth rotates around its axis from west to east.
It takes 24 hours to complete one rotation.
During rotation, it is night in the part of the earth facing away from the sun, and day in the part facing the sunlight.
Because of the following reasons the International Date Line is of great importance.
The line helps to determine the time of a place and overcomes the problem of date and time determination.
A ship travelling west when crosses this line it calculates its time one day forward.
Similarly, a ship travelling east when crosses this line calculates its time one day behind.
Effects of rotation: The following are the effects of rotation of earth.
Because of rotation the cycle of day and night occurs.
It is daytime in the part of the earth facing the sun, and the other side away from sunlight experiences night.
The meeting line of day and night on the surface of earth is the penumbral line.
The occurrence of Experiment showing day and night day and night can be demonstrated with the help of an experiment.
In a dark room a candle is facing the candle is illuminated, while the part away is dark.
Similarly, the side of the earth on which the sunlight falls experiences day, while the other part has night.
The rotational motion of the earth affects and changes the direction of the winds and ocean currents.
Rotation also helps to estimate the time.
The 24 hour solar day is divided into minutes and seconds.

As the sunrays fall obliquely on the north and south of this region, it is less hot there.
Rotation of the earth also causes the high and low tides.
Revolution: In addition to rotating on its own axis, the earth is also revolving around the sun along its orbit.
It takes one year or 365 days for the earth to complete one revolution around the sun.
The time taken to complete one revolution is the solar year.
The earth travels along the orbit at a velocity of about 106,260 kilometre per hour, or 30 kilometre per second.
The actual time taken to complete one revolution is 365 days, 5 hours, 48 minutes, 47 seconds.
The extra day is added to the 28 days in the month of February.
The year in which the extra day is added to make February a 29 day month, is called Leap Year.
The sun gives light and heat.
The season at any time in a place depends of the heat received from the sun.
When the days are long more sunrays fall on the earth than when the days are short.
The cycle of season change occurs along with the change in the length of day and night.
The different seasons is characterised by differences in average temperature and in the amount of time that the sun is in the sky each day.
The seasons occur because the axis on which the earth turns is tilted with respect to the plane of the earth's orbit around the sun.
When it is summer in the northern hemisphere, this hemisphere is tilted toward the sun;
this corresponds to winter in the southern hemisphere, when the southern hemisphere is tilted away from the sun.
The northern hemisphere's autumnal equinox occurs in September and marks the beginning of autumn.
In the southern hemisphere, the vernal equinox occurs in September and the autumnal equinox occurs in March.
At these times, the sun appears to be directly over the earth's equator.
The lengths of day and night are then equal over almost all the earth, except at the poles.
the southern hemisphere then experiences summer with more warmth, and the northern hemisphere has its winter.
The hemisphere most tilted toward the sun experiences its longest day of sunlight and its shortest night.
The other hemisphere experiences its shortest day of sunlight and its longest night.
The sunrays fall perpendicularly on the equator.
The northern hemisphere's vernal equinox occurs in March and marks the beginning of spring.
